	sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	NET SALES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Consolidated sales
	decreased to $9,170&nbsp;million from $9,240&nbsp;million in 2014. Excluding currency effects, the organic sales growth
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page 41) was 8%. All regions of the Company showed organic
	sales growth
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page 41) in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Sales of
<B>
	airbag products
</B>
	(including steering wheels) were favorably impacted by higher sales of replacement inflators, inflatable curtains and steering wheels.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Sales of
<B>
	seatbelt products
</B>
	were particularly strong in Europe and North America. The global trend towards more advanced and higher
	value-added seatbelt systems continued globally.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Organic sales
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page
	41) for
<B>
	passive safety electronics products
</B>
	(mainly airbag control modules and remote sensing units) grew primarily from higher sales in China and South Korea.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The strong increase in sales of
<B>
	active safety products
</B>
	(automotive radars, night vision systems, cameras with driver assist systems,
	positioning systems and brake control systems) resulted particularly from higher sales of radar related products, primarily as a result of Mercedes&#146; increased demand for driver assistance products. Increased sales of vision systems to BMW also
	contributed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For the full year 2015, sales in the Americas represent 35% of total sales, Asia (China, Japan, RoA) 34%, and Europe 31%.
	Sales continue to be balanced across the regions. Organic growth
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page 41) was particularly strong in Europe, North America and Japan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Sales from Autoliv&#146;s companies in
<B>
	China
</B>
	grew organically
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page
	41) by more than 2%. This was the result of strong sales to certain local OEMs, partly mitigated by lower sales to certain global OEM&#146;s.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Organic sales
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page 41) from Autoliv&#146;s companies in
<B>
	Japan
</B>
	grew
	by close to 10%. The growth was primarily driven by sales of replacement inflators. Strong sales of models from Toyota and Nissan also contributed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Organic sales
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page 41) from Autoliv&#146;s companies in the
<B>
	RoA
</B>
	grew by more than 6%. The growth was driven by strong sales growth in India driven by models from Hyundai and in Thailand, primarily with models from Mitsubishi. A slight sales growth in South Korea was primarily the result of sales to models from
	Hyundai/Kia.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Organic sales
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page 41) from Autoliv&#146;s companies in
	the
<B>
	Americas
</B>
	increased by more than 9% and were positively impacted by sales growth to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	OEMs in North America, mainly models from Hyundai/Kia, Mercedes, and Honda. Sales of replacement inflators
	also contributed positively to the growth.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Organic sales
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page 41)
	from Autoliv&#146;s companies in
<B>
	Europe
</B>
	increased rapidly by close to 10%. Models from VW, Ford, Mercedes, Hyundai/Kia, Fiat-Chrysler and Renault were the strongest contributors to growth.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	GROSS PROFIT
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Gross profit for the full
	year 2015 increased by more than $40&nbsp;million, compared to the same period last year, primarily as a result of the higher gross margin. Gross margin increased by 0.6pp compared to the same period of 2014, mainly as a result of higher organic
	sales, favorable currency effects, positive product mix and raw material savings, partially offset by costs related to the investments for capacity and growth.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	OPERATING INCOME
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating income
	increased by around $5&nbsp;million to $728&nbsp;million and the operating margin by 0.1pp to 7.9%. The increase in the operating margin was mainly due to the higher organic sales, partly offset by higher costs for capacity alignments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Excluding costs for capacity alignment and antitrust related matter (including antitrust settlements) the adjusted operating margin
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page 41) was 9.7% up from 9.1% for the same period one year ago, mainly as a result of higher organic sales, favorable currency effects, positive product mix and raw material savings,
	partially offset by costs related to the investments for capacity and growth.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	INTEREST EXPENSE, NET
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Interest expense, net increased by $4&nbsp;million to $62&nbsp;million compared to 2014. The increase relates primarily to recent financing
	(see Note 12 to Consolidated Financial Statements included herein). In addition, during 2015, Autoliv had a net debt position of $232&nbsp;million on average, compared to a net cash position of $260&nbsp;million on average in 2014 (see Treasury
	Activities on page 48).
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage98"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	INCOME TAXES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Income before taxes increased by close to $9&nbsp;million to $676&nbsp;million, $4&nbsp;million more than the increase in operating income.
	Income tax expense was $218&nbsp;million compared to $198&nbsp;million in 2014. The effective tax rate was 32.3% compared to 29.7% for the full year 2014. In 2015 discrete tax items, net, were not material for the full year 2015, compared to 2014
	when discrete tax items, net, decreased the rate by 0.7pp. See Note 4 to Consolidated Financial Statements included herein.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	NET INCOME AND EARNINGS
	PER SHARE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net income attributable to controlling interest amounted to $457&nbsp;million compared to $468&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	EPS amounted to $5.17 assuming dilution compared to $5.06 for 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The weighted average number of shares outstanding assuming dilution decreased to 88.4&nbsp;million compared to 92.4&nbsp;million for the full
	year 2014.
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage99"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:16PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Liquidity, Resources and Financial Position
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	CASH FROM OPERATIONS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Cash flow from
	operations, together with available financial resources and credit facilities, are expected to be sufficient to fund Autoliv&#146;s anticipated working capital requirements, capital expenditures and future dividend payments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Cash provided by operating activities was $868&nbsp;million in 2016, $751&nbsp;million in 2015 and $713&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	While management of cash and debt is important to the overall business, it is not part of the operational management&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	day-to-day
</FONT>
</FONT>
	responsibilities. We therefore focus on operationally derived working capital and have set a policy that the operating working capital should not exceed 10% of the
	last
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	12-month
</FONT>
	net sales.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, operating working capital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure see page 41) stood at $579&nbsp;million corresponding to 5.7% of net sales compared to $570&nbsp;million and 6.2%, respectively, at December&nbsp;31, 2015. This ratio was reduced by 0.4pp in
	2016 and by 1.0pp in 2015 by provisions for capacity alignment and other restructuring charges, and favorably impacted by 1.2pp and 1.4pp, respectively, from the sale of receivables and discounting of notes totaling $113&nbsp;million in 2016 and
	$125&nbsp;million in 2015 (see Treasury Activities on page 48).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Days receivables outstanding (see page 87 for definition) increased to 74
	at December&nbsp;31, 2016 from 73 days on December&nbsp;31, 2015. Factoring agreements did not have any material effect on days receivables outstanding for 2016, 2015 or 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Days inventory outstanding (definition on page 87) were 33 at December&nbsp;31, 2016 unchanged from one year earlier.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	CAPITAL EXPENDITURES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Cash generated by
	operating activities continued to sufficiently cover capital expenditures for property, plant and equipment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Capital expenditures, gross
	were $507&nbsp;million in 2016, $466&nbsp;million in 2015 and $456&nbsp;million in 2014, corresponding to 5.0%, 5.1% and 4.9% of net sales, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Capital expenditures, net amounted to $499&nbsp;million and depreciation and amortization totaled $383&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to
	$450&nbsp;million and $319&nbsp;million, respectively, for the full year 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Capital expenditures for 2017 are expected to be at the
	high end of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	5-6%
</FONT>
	of sales range to support our growth strategy.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During 2016, investments in
	production capacity to support further growth, vertical integration and inflator replacement business continued. Major investments were mainly made in Europe, North America, China and Active Safety.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During 2015, major investments were made for the inflator replacement business, continued investments for growth in China, as well as
	investments in production lines related to new technologies and growth in Europe.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2014, major investments were made to increase
	manufacturing capacity of inflators in Asia and the U.S. Investments to increase inflator manufacturing capacity in Asia has primarily been in China.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Also, in China, large investments were made to increase manufacturing capacity for Airbag cushions. Large investments were also commenced to
	meet increased demand for manufacturing of electronic products in all regions. In addition, expansion of five facilities in Europe was commenced for manufacturing of seatbelt, webbing, cushion sewing and steering wheels to meet increased demand and
	to support the ongoing restructuring program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	BUSINESS COMBINATIONS, ACQUISITIONS AND DIVESTMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Historically, the Company has made many acquisitions. Generally, we focus on two principal growth areas around our core business with the
	greatest potential, active safety systems and growth markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In March 2016, the Company acquired a 51% interest in the entities that
	formed Autoliv-Nissin Brake Systems (ANBS) for approximately $263&nbsp;million in cash. ANBS designs, manufactures and sells products in the brake control and actuation systems business. Nissin Kogyo retained a 49% interest in the entities that
	formed ANBS. The Company has management and operational control of ANBS and consolidate the results of operation and balance sheet from ANBS. The transaction has been accounted for as a business combination. The recognized goodwill of
	$217.8&nbsp;million reflects expected synergies from combining Autoliv&#146;s global reach and customer base with Nissin Kogyo&#146;s world leading expertise (including workforce) and technology in brake control and actuation systems. A significant
	portion of the goodwill is deductible for tax purposes (for more information, see Note 2, Business Combinations on page 66).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In August
	2015 the Company acquired the &#147;Automotive Solutions&#148; business of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	M/A-COM
</FONT>
	Technology Solutions Holdings, Inc. (MACOM), which is a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	carve-out
</FONT>
	of the automotive
	business of MACOM, through the acquisition of all of the shares of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	M/A-COM
</FONT>
	Auto Solutions, Inc., for total consideration of approximately $138.5&nbsp;million. The transaction has been accounted for as a
	business combination. The recognized goodwill of approximately $85&nbsp;million mainly reflects the expected synergies from combining the Active Safety operations of the Company and the acquired &#147;Automotive solutions&#148; business from MACOM.
	The goodwill is expected to be fully deductible for tax purposes. From the date of acquisition through December&nbsp;31, 2015, the MACOM business reported net sales of $30&nbsp;million. No business combinations or acquisitions occurred in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	FINANCING ACTIVITIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2016 cash used
	in financing activities amounted to $200&nbsp;million. In 2015, cash of $319&nbsp;million was used for financing activities. In 2014 cash provided by financing activities amounted to $226&nbsp;million. Gross debt increased by $4&nbsp;million to
	$1,543&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and decreased by $62&nbsp;million to $1,539&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. There were no share repurchases made during 2016. In 2015, the Company repurchased common shares amounting to
	$104&nbsp;million, see Note 13 to Consolidated Financial Statements included herein. Cash and cash equivalents decreased by $107&nbsp;million to $1,227&nbsp;million in 2016 and decreased by $195&nbsp;million to $1,334&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company&#146;s net debt
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure see page 41) position increased by
	$112&nbsp;million to $313&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016. During 2015, the net debt position increased by $140&nbsp;million to a net debt position of $202&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	FOREIGN EARNINGS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Substantially all of
	the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	earnings are permanently reinvested outside the U.S. The permanently reinvested earnings are, therefore, not planned to be repatriated to the U.S. and are not necessary to fund our
	U.S. operations or requirements. The U.S. companies have sufficient liquidity to finance all currently projected funding needs in the U.S. for the foreseeable future. Total cash and cash equivalents as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 was
	$1.2&nbsp;billion, whereof $0.5&nbsp;billion was in the U.S.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	INCOME TAXES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company has reserves for taxes that may become payable in future periods as a result of tax audits.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At any given time, the Company is undergoing tax audits covering multiple years in several tax jurisdictions. Ultimate outcomes are uncertain
	but could, in future periods, have a significant impact on the Company&#146;s cash flows. See discussions of income taxes under Significant Accounting Policies on page 51 and Note 1 on page 62, also see Note 4 to Consolidated Financial Statements
	included herein.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	PENSION ARRANGEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company has defined benefit pension plans covering nearly half of the U.S. employees. The Company froze participation in the U.S. plans to
	exclude employees hired after December&nbsp;31, 2003. Many of the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	employees are also covered by pension arrangements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company&#146;s pension liability (i.e. the actual funded status) for its U.S. and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans was $238&nbsp;million compared to $197&nbsp;million one year earlier. The plans had a net unamortized actuarial loss of $135&nbsp;million recorded in Accumulated Other Comprehensive (Loss) Income in
	the Consolidated Statement of Equity at December&nbsp;31, 2016, compared to $114&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The amortization of this loss is expected to be $8&nbsp;million in 2017.
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage100"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The liability increase in 2016 of $41&nbsp;million was mainly due to a decrease in the discount
	rate for many of the plans and the transfer of the defined benefit plan in Japan in connection with the acquisition of ANBS, partly offset by foreign currency translation effects of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans. The
	liability decrease in 2015 of $36&nbsp;million was mainly due to an increase in the discount rate for many of the plans and foreign currency translation effects of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	plans, partly offset by updated
	salary scale assumption in the U.S. plans and changes in the Canadian dollar exchange rate.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Pension expense
	associated with the defined benefit plans was $28&nbsp;million in 2016, $35&nbsp;million in 2015 and $25&nbsp;million in 2014 and is expected to be $32&nbsp;million in 2017. The decrease in pension expense in 2016 of $7&nbsp;million was mainly due
	to a prior year increase in discount rates. The increase in pension expense in 2015 of $10&nbsp;million was mainly due to a prior year decrease in discount rates. In 2014 the decrease in pension expense by $15&nbsp;million was mainly due to a prior
	year increase in the discount rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company contributed $17&nbsp;million to its defined benefit plans in 2016, $16&nbsp;million in
	2015 and $16&nbsp;million in 2014. The Company expects to contribute $15&nbsp;million to these plans in 2017 and is currently projecting a yearly funding at approximately the same level in the subsequent years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For further information about retirement plans see Note 18 to Consolidated Financial Statements included herein.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	SHAREHOLDER RETURNS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Total cash dividends
	paid were $203&nbsp;million in 2016, $196&nbsp;million in 2015 and $195&nbsp;million in 2014. The Company has raised the dividend from 50 cents per share in 2013 to 58 cents per share in 2016 (see following table). The Board of Directors has
	declared a dividend of 58 cents per share for the first quarter and 60 cents per share for the second quarter of 2017. The annualized dividend amount of $205&nbsp;million, is based on 58 cents per share and the number of shares outstanding at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	There were no share repurchases in 2016. During the first quarter in 2015, the Company repurchased
	0.9&nbsp;million shares for cash of $104&nbsp;million, including commissions. During 2014, the Company repurchased 6.2&nbsp;million shares for cash of $616&nbsp;million, including commissions. In total, Autoliv has repurchased 43.1&nbsp;million
	shares between May 2000 and December 2016 for cash of $2,341&nbsp;million, including commissions. The maximum number of shares that are available to be purchased under the stock repurchase program at December&nbsp;31, 2016 is 4.4&nbsp;million. There
	is no expiration date for the share repurchase authorization in order to provide management flexibility in the Company&#146;s share repurchases. For further information see Note 13 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included herein.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	1) Declared.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	EQUITY
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During 2016, total equity increased by 13.2% or $458&nbsp;million to $3,926&nbsp;million. This was mainly due to a net income of
	$562&nbsp;million, $252&nbsp;million from the recognition of a minority interest in ANBS and a $16&nbsp;million effect from stock incentives. These effects were partly offset by $206&nbsp;million for dividends, $156&nbsp;million due to negative
	currency effects and $17&nbsp;million due to pension liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During 2015, total equity increased by 0.8% or $26&nbsp;million to
	$3,468&nbsp;million. This was due to net income of $457&nbsp;million, $35&nbsp;million due to pension liabilities and a $29&nbsp;million effect from stock incentives. Equity was reduced by $197&nbsp;million due to dividends, $192&nbsp;million due to
	negative currency effects and $104&nbsp;million due to share repurchases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	IMPACT OF INFLATION [AND RAW MATERIAL PRICES]
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Inflation has generally not had a significant impact on the Company&#146;s financial position or results of operations. The impact of raw
	material prices in 2015 and 2016 was positive by $40&nbsp;million and $33&nbsp;million, respectively. For 2017, we currently expect an unfavorable impact of $31&nbsp;million from increasing raw material prices.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Changes in most raw material prices affect the Company with a time lag, which is usually three to six months for most materials (see Component
	Costs on page 52).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In many growth markets, inflation is relatively high, especially labor inflation. We have managed to offset this
	negative effect mainly by labor productivity improvements. However, no assurance can be given that this will continue to be possible going forward.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	PERSONNEL
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During the past three years,
	total headcount (permanent employees and temporary personnel) has risen by 24% from the beginning of 2014 to 70,293 in 2016. This reflects the rebound in the cyclical automotive business as well as the combined effect of long-term growth of global
	LVP, strong demand for safer vehicles and Autoliv&#146;s market share gains, which all drive the need for additional manufacturing personnel.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During 2016, headcount increased by 6,200 including impact from acquisitions by 1,733 people. During 2015, headcount increased by 4,000
	including impact from acquisitions by 23 people. During 2014, headcount increased by 3,500, with no impact from acquisitions. Excluding acquisitions headcount increased by 7% during 2016, 7% during 2015 and 6% during 2014, which should be compared
	to increases in organic sales of 7%, 8% and 6% for the same years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At the end of 2016, 75% of total headcount was in BCC compared to 72%
	at the beginning of 2014. Furthermore, 68% of total headcount at December&nbsp;31, 2016 was direct workers in manufacturing compared to 72% at the beginning of 2014, while 13% of total headcount at December&nbsp;31, 2016 were temporary employees,
	compared to 17% at the beginning of 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Compensation to directors and executive officers is reported, as is customary for U.S. public
	companies, in Autoliv&#146;s proxy statement, which will be available to shareholders in March 2017.
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage101"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:16PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Treasury Activities
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	CREDIT ARRANGEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In July 2016, the
	Company refinanced its existing revolving credit facility (RCF) of $1,100&nbsp;million. The facility is syndicated among 14 banks and matures in 2021. It also has two extension options where Autoliv can request the banks to extend the maturity to
	2022 and 2023, respectively, on the first and second anniversaries of the loan facility, a so called 5+1+1 structure. The Company pays a commitment fee on the undrawn amount of 0.08%, representing 35% of the applicable margin, which is 0.225% (given
	the Company&#146;s rating of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	&#147;A-&#148;
</FONT>
	from Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s at December&nbsp;31, 2016). Borrowings under the facility are unsecured and bear interest based on the relevant LIBOR or IBOR
	rate. The commitment is available for general corporate purposes. Borrowings are repayable at any time and in their entirety at the expiration date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company&#146;s unutilized long-term credit facilities were $1.1&nbsp;billion, represented by the RCF. This
	facility is not subject to any financial covenants nor is any other substantial financing of Autoliv. The Company had a net debt position
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(non-U.S.
</FONT>
	GAAP measure, see page 41) at year end 2016 and 2015 of
	$313&nbsp;million and $202&nbsp;million, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2014, the Company issued and sold $1.25&nbsp;billion of long-term debt
	securities in a U.S. Private Placement pursuant to a Note Purchase and Guaranty Agreement dated April&nbsp;23, 2014, by and among Autoliv ASP Inc., the Company and the purchasers listed therein. See Note 12 to Consolidated Financial Statements
	included herein for additional information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During 2016 and 2015, the Company sold receivables and discounted notes related to selected
	customers. These factoring arrangements increase cash while reducing accounts receivable and customer risks. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had received $113&nbsp;million for sold receivables without recourse and discounted notes with a
	discount of $2&nbsp;million during the year, compared to $125&nbsp;million at year end 2015 with a discount of $2&nbsp;million recorded in Other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-operating
</FONT>
	items, net.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Autoliv has a long-term credit rating from Standard and Poor&#146;s of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	A-
</FONT>
	which is in line with the
	Company&#146;s objective of maintaining a strong investment grade rating.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	NUMBER OF SHARES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, 88.2&nbsp;million shares were outstanding (net of 14.6&nbsp;million treasury shares), a 0.1% increase from
	88.1&nbsp;million one year earlier.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The number of shares outstanding is expected to increase by 0.7&nbsp;million when all Restricted
	Stock Units (RSU) &amp; Performance Shares (PSs) vest and if all stock options (SOs) to key employees are exercised, see Note 15 to Consolidated Financial Statements included herein.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For calculating earnings per share assuming dilution, Autoliv follows the Treasury Stock Method.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	There were no share repurchases made during 2016. The maximum number of shares that may yet be purchased under the stock repurchase program
	amount to 4.4&nbsp;million shares at December&nbsp;31, 2016. In total, Autoliv has repurchased 43.1&nbsp;million shares between May 2000 and December 2016 for cash of $2,341&nbsp;million, including commissions. The average cost per share for all
	repurchased shares to date is $54.36. Purchases can be made from time to time as market and business conditions warrant in open market, negotiated or block transactions. There is no expiration date for the repurchase program in order to provide
	management flexibility in the Company&#146;s share repurchases.
</P>
<EFX_BALANCE_SHEET>
<A NAME="FIS_BALANCE_SHEET"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:16PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Contractual Obligations and Commitments
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_BALANCE_SHEET>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	1) Excludes contingent liabilities arising from litigation, arbitration, income taxes or regulatory actions. 2) Debt-Related
	Derivatives (DRD), see Note 12 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included herein. 3) Expected contributions for funded and unfunded defined benefit plans exclude payments beyond 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Contractual obligations include debt, lease and purchase obligations that are enforceable and legally binding on the Company.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-controlling
</FONT>
	interest and restructuring obligations are not included in this table. The major employee obligations as a result of restructuring are disclosed in Note 10 to Consolidated Financial Statements
	included herein.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Debt obligations including Debt-Related Derivatives (DRD):
</B>
	For material contractual provisions, see Note 12 to
	Consolidated Financial Statements included herein. The debt obligations include capital lease obligations, which mainly relate to property and plants in Japan and China, as well as the impact of revaluation to fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Fixed-interest obligations including DRD:
</B>
	These obligations include interest on debt and credit agreements relating to periods after
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, as adjusted by DRD, excluding fees on the revolving credit facility and interest on debts with no defined amortization plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Operating lease obligations:
</B>
	The Company leases certain offices, manufacturing and research buildings, machinery, automobiles and data
	processing and other equipment. Such operating leases, some of which are
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cancelable
</FONT>
	and include renewals, expire on various dates. See Note 17 to Consolidated Financial Statements included herein.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Unconditional purchase obligations:
</B>
	There are no unconditional purchase obligations other than short-term obligations related to
	inventory, services, tooling, and property, plant and equipment purchased in the ordinary course of business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Purchase agreements with
	suppliers entered into in the ordinary course of business do not generally include fixed quantities. Quantities and delivery dates are established in &#147;call off plans&#148; accessible electronically for all customers and suppliers involved.
	Communicated &#147;call off plans&#148; for production material from suppliers are normally reflected in equivalent commitments from Autoliv customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Pension contribution requirements:
</B>
	The Company sponsors defined benefit plans that cover a significant portion of our U.S. employees
	and certain
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	employees. The pension plans in the U.S. are funded in conformity with the minimum funding requirements of the Pension Protection Act of 2006. Funding for our pension plans in other
	countries is based upon plan provisions, actuarial recommendations and/or statutory requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2017, the expected contribution to
	all plans, including direct payments to retirees, is $15&nbsp;million, of which the major contribution is $7&nbsp;million for our U.S. pension plans. Due to volatility associated with future changes in interest rates and plan asset returns, the
	Company cannot predict with reasonable reliability the timing and amounts of future funding requirements, and therefore the above excludes payments beyond 2017. We may elect to make contributions in excess of the minimum funding requirements for the
	U.S. plans in response to investment performance and changes in interest rates, or when we believe that it is financially advantageous to do so and based on other capital requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Excluded from the above are expected contributions of less than $1&nbsp;million due in 2017 with respect to our other post-employment benefit
	(OPEB) plans, which represent the expected benefit payments to participants as costs are incurred. See Note 18 to Consolidated Financial Statements included herein.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
	Other
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-current
</FONT>
	liabilities reflected on the balance sheet:
</B>
	These consist mainly of local
	governmental liabilities and an
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	earn-out
</FONT>
	payment in connection with the acquisition of the automotive business of MACOM (see Note 2).
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage102"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	OFF-BALANCE
</FONT>
	SHEET ARRANGEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company does not have any
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	off-balance
</FONT>
	sheet arrangements that have, or are reasonably likely to
	have, a material current or future effect on its financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage103"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:16PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Significant Accounting Policies and Critical Accounting Estimates
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	NEW ACCOUNTING PRONOUNCEMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company
	has considered all applicable recently issued accounting guidance. The Company has summarized in Note 1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements each of the recently issued accounting pronouncements and stated the impact or whether management is
	continuing to assess the impact. See page 64 for additional information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	APPLICATION OF CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company&#146;s significant accounting policies are disclosed in Note 1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included herein. Senior
	management has discussed the development and selection of critical accounting estimates and disclosures with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors. The application of accounting policies necessarily requires judgments and the use of
	estimates by a Company&#146;s management. Actual results could differ from these estimates. By their nature, these judgments are subject to an inherent degree of uncertainty. These judgments are based on our historical experience, terms of existing
	contracts, and management&#146;s evaluation of trends in the industry, information provided by our customers and information available from other outside sources, as appropriate. The Company considers an accounting estimate to be critical if:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	It requires management to make assumptions about matters that were uncertain at the time of the estimate, and
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR STYLE = "PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID">
<TD WIDTH="1%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY" STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
	Changes in the estimate or different estimates that could have been selected would have had a material impact
	on our financial condition or results of operations.
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	REVENUE RECOGNITION
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Revenues are recognized when there is evidence of a sales agreement, delivery of goods has occurred, the sales price is fixed and determinable
	and the collectability of revenue is reasonably assured. The Company records revenue from the sale of manufactured products upon shipment to customers and transfer of title and risk of loss under standard commercial terms.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Accruals are made for retroactive price adjustments if probable and can be reasonably estimated. Net sales exclude taxes assessed by a
	governmental authority that are directly imposed on revenue-producing transactions between the Company and its customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE
	ALLOWANCE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Establishing valuation allowances for doubtful accounts requires the use of estimates and judgment in regard to the risk
	exposure and ultimate realization. The allowance for doubtful accounts is established based upon analysis of trade receivables for known collectability issues, including bankruptcies, and aging of receivables at the end of each period. Changes to
	the Company&#146;s assumptions could materially affect our recorded allowance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	BUSINESS COMBINATIONS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In accordance with accounting guidance for the provisions in FASB ASC 805, Business Combinations, the Company allocates the purchase price of
	an acquired business to its identifiable assets and liabilities based on estimated fair values. The excess of the purchase price over the amount allocated to the assets and liabilities, if any, is recorded as goodwill. In addition, an acquisition
	may include a contingent consideration component, such as our acquisition agreement for MACOM during 2015. The fair value of the contingent consideration is estimated as of the date of the acquisition and is recorded as part of the purchase price.
	Each quarter this contingent consideration is
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-measured
</FONT>
	using the discounted cash flow method.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company uses all available information to estimate fair values. The Company has engaged outside appraisal firms to assist in the fair
	value determination of identifiable intangible assets and any other significant assets or liabilities. The Company adjusts the preliminary purchase price allocation, as necessary, up to one year after the acquisition closing date as the Company
	obtains more information regarding asset valuations and liabilities assumed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company&#146;s purchase price allocation methodology
	contains uncertainties because it requires management to make assumptions and to apply judgment to estimate the fair value of acquired assets and liabilities. Management estimates the fair value of assets and liabilities based upon quoted market
	prices, the carrying value of the acquired assets and widely accepted valuation techniques, including discounted cash flows and market multiple analyses. Unanticipated events or circumstances may occur which could affect the accuracy of our fair
	value estimates, including assumptions regarding industry economic factors and business strategies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Other estimates used in determining
	fair value include, but are not limited to, future cash flows or income related to intangibles, market rate assumptions, actuarial assumptions for benefit plans and appropriate discount rates. The Company estimates the fair value based upon
	assumptions believed to be reasonable, but that are inherently uncertain, and therefore, may not be realized. Accordingly, there can be no assurance that the estimates, assumptions, and values reflected in the valuations will be realized, and actual
	results could vary materially.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	INVENTORY RESERVES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Inventories are evaluated based on individual or, in some cases, groups of inventory items. Reserves are established to reduce the value of
	inventories to the lower of cost or market, with market generally defined as net realizable value for finished goods and replacement cost for raw materials and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	work-in-process.
</FONT>
</FONT>
	Excess inventories are quantities of items that exceed anticipated sales or usage for a reasonable period. The Company has guidelines for calculating
	provisions for excess inventories based on the number of months of inventories on hand compared to anticipated sales or usage. Management uses its judgment to forecast sales or usage and to determine what constitutes a reasonable period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	There can be no assurance that the amount ultimately realized for receivables and inventories will not be materially different than that
	assumed in the calculation of the reserves.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	GOODWILL AND INTANGIBLES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company performs an annual impairment review of goodwill in the fourth quarter of each year following the Company&#146;s annual forecasting
	process. Management uses its judgment to determine the Company&#146;s reporting units for goodwill impairment testing. The estimated fair market value of goodwill is determined by the discounted cash flow method. The Company discounts projected
	operating cash flows using its weighted average cost of capital. Estimating the fair value requires the Company to make judgments about appropriate discount rates, growth rates, relevant comparable company earnings multiples and the amount and
	timing of expected future cash flows. If the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, an entity must perform a second step to measure the amount of the impairment loss, if any. The second step requires a reporting unit to
	compare its implied fair value of goodwill to its carrying amount. If the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value, the reporting unit would recognize an impairment loss for that excess.
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage104"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	To supplement this analysis, the Company compares the market value of its equity, calculated by
	reference to the quoted market prices of its shares, with the book value of its equity. There were no goodwill impairments in 2014-2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company reviews indefinite-lived intangible assets for impairment annually or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances
	indicate the assets might be impaired. Similar to the goodwill impairment test described above, the Company performs a quantitative impairment test by comparing the estimated fair of the asset, based upon its forecasted cash flows, to its carrying
	value. Other intangible assets with definite lives are amortized over their useful lives and are subject to impairment testing only if events or circumstances indicate that the asset might be impaired, as described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	RECALL PROVISIONS AND WARRANTY OBLIGATIONS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company records liabilities for product recalls when probable claims are identified and when it is possible to reasonably estimate costs.
	Recall costs are costs incurred when the customer decides to formally recall a product due to a known or suspected safety concern. Product recall costs typically include the cost of the product being replaced as well as the customer&#146;s cost of
	the recall, including labor to remove and replace the defective part. In some cases portions of the product recall costs are reimbursed by an insurance company. Actual costs incurred could differ from the amounts estimated, requiring adjustments to
	these reserves in future periods. It is possible that changes in our assumptions or future product recall issues could materially affect our financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Estimating warranty obligations requires the Company to forecast the resolution of existing claims and expected future claims on products
	sold. The Company bases the estimate on historical trends of units sold and payment amounts, combined with our current understanding of the status of existing claims and discussions with our customers. These estimates are
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-evaluated
</FONT>
	on an ongoing basis. Actual warranty obligations could differ from the amounts estimated requiring adjustments to existing reserves in future periods. Due to the uncertainty and potential volatility of
	the factors contributing to developing these estimates, changes in our assumptions could materially affect our results of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	RESTRUCTURING
	PROVISIONS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company defines restructuring expense to include costs directly associated with capacity alignment programs, plus exit
	or disposal activities. Estimates of restructuring charges are based on information available at the time such charges are recorded. In general, management anticipates that restructuring activities will be completed within a time frame such that
	significant changes to the exit plan are not likely.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Due to inherent uncertainty involved in estimating restructuring expenses, actual
	amounts paid for such activities may differ from amounts initially estimated.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	DEFINED BENEFIT PENSION PLANS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company has defined benefit pension plans in thirteen countries. The most significant plans exist in the U.S. These plans represent 58% of
	the Company&#146;s total pension benefit obligation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Company, in consultation with its actuarial advisors, determines certain key
	assumptions to be used in calculating the projected benefit obligation and annual pension expense. For the U.S. plans, the assumptions used for calculating the 2016 pension expense were a discount rate of 4.50%, expected rate of increase in
	compensation levels of 2.65%, and an expected long-term rate of return on plan assets of 7.08%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The assumptions used in calculating the
	U.S. benefit obligations disclosed as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 were a discount rate of 4.15% and an expected
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	age-based
</FONT>
	rate of increase in compensation levels of 2.65%. The discount rate for the U.S. plans
	has been set based on the rates of return of high-quality fixed-income investments currently available at the measurement date and are expected to be available during the period the benefits will be paid. The expected rate of increase in
	compensation levels and long-term return on plan assets are determined based on a number of factors and must take into account long-term expectations and reflect the financial environment in the respective local markets. At December&nbsp;31, 2016,
	56% of the U.S. plan assets were invested in equities, which is in line with the target of 55%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The table below illustrates the
	sensitivity of the U.S. net periodic benefit cost and projected U.S. benefit obligation to a 1pp change in the discount rate, decrease in return on plan assets and increase in compensation levels for the U.S. plans (in millions). The use of
	actuarial assumptions is an area of management&#146;s estimate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	78

	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Compensation levels
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
